JSON

What is JSON

JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation. It is a data representation format, similar to XML. It's used widely across web development and with APIs and many other places in programming.

It is extremely lightweight, has a small file size, is easy to read, and it integrates very well with JavaScript - as it is a superset of the language.

Everything written in JSON is valid JavaScript.

Nearly every major language has some form of integration for JSON, making working with JSON very easy with different languages.

In short, JSON is a:

  • Data representation format;
  • commonly used for APIs and configs;
  • lightweight and easy to read/write;
  • Integrates easily with most languages.

JSON Types

As a data representation format, JSON can handle common types of data, such as:

  • strings → "Hello World";
  • numbers → 10 1.5 -30 1.2e10;
  • booleans → true false;
  • null;
  • arrays → [1, 2, 3] ["Hello", "World"];
  • objects → { "key": "value" } { "age": 30 }.

Using JSON inside a file

To start a JSON file, you need to first create a file with the .json extention at the end.

Within the file you can place any of the prior shown data files on their own or within objects, and it will function as valid JSON.

However, having but a single string or number within your .json file is not very purposeful. You'll usually have an array or object as a top level of the file, and nest other objects, strings, arrays, and data within it.

example user.json

{
    // standard `key` notation...
    "key": "value", // double quotes, seperated with commas.
    "key": "value",

    "name": "Thomas",
    "favouriteNumber": 3, // numbers do not have to wrapped in double quotes.
    "isProgrammer": true, // booleans also do not need double quotes.
    "hobbies": ["Weight Lifting", "Bowling", "Video Games"],
    "friends": [
        { // placing more user objects inside of an array...
        "name": "Jim",
        "favouriteNumber": 7,
        "isProgrammer": false,
        "friends": [...] // No comma!
    }]
}

The JSON object above shows its effectiveness in managing a hierarchy of data, allowing the nesting of objects in multiple layers.

companies.json & implementation into HTML

In the file companies.json we're going to store different companies and each of these companies is going to have a name, number of employees, a CEO, and a 1-5 rating.

[ // companies.json
    // first objects...
    {
        "name": "Big Corpos",
        "numberOfEmployees": 10000,
        "ceo": "Mary Morteqai",
        "rating": 3.6
    },
    // second object...
    {
        "name": "Minimax",
        "numberOfEmployees": 32,
        "ceo": null,
        "rating": 4.1
    },
    // third object...
    {
        "name": "Garage Gear",
        "numberOfEmployees": 2,
        "ceo": null,
        "rating": 3.2
    }
]

JSON in HTML

Placing the above code into an HTML file is done within the <script> tags, and is processed like JavaScript code.

<html>
    <head>
        <title>JSON Example</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <script type="text/javascript">
            let companies = [
                {
                    "name": "Big Corpos",
                    "numberOfEmployees": 10000,
                    "ceo": "Mary Morteqai",
                    "rating": 3.6
                },
                {
                    "name": "Minimax",
                    "numberOfEmployees": 32,
                    "ceo": null,
                    "rating": 4.1
                },
                {
                    "name": "Garage Gear",
                    "numberOfEmployees": 2,
                    "ceo": null,
                    "rating": 3.2
                }
            ]

            console.log(companies);
        </script>
    </body>
</html>

Parsing JSON into functioning JavaScript

Most of the time data returned from JSON will return as a string, not a JavaScript object—making it invalid to use in JavaScript.

In order to use JSON strings as a valid JavaScript object, we use JSON.parse() to parse the string into valid JS, allowing you to do everything you can do as with a regular JS object.

console.log(JSON.parse(companies));
// returns: companies.json as a JavaScript Object.

Selecting variables with a JSON file is also possible:

console.log(JSON.parse(companies)[0].name) // Prints out the name of the first company.
